awd_titl_txt: EAPSI: Exploring How Perceptions of Autonomy Influence Cross-Cultural Differences in Cognition
awd_abstract_narration:
Americans and Chinese think about and perceive the world differently. Americans often focus their attention on specific objects in their field of vision and view them as independent from other objects in their environment. Chinese often focus their attention on all objects in their field of vision and view them as interdependent with their environment. Why does this happen? In collaboration with Dr. Shihui Han of Peking University in Beijing, China, an expert in cross-cultural psychology and social neuroscience, the EAPSI fellow will investigate why these differences arise. Ultimately, this research will lead to greater understanding about the causes of cultural differences in cognition and perception thereby potentially contributing to enhancement of mutual understanding between nations of distinctive cultures.

This project deals with the hypothesis that the differences in analytic and holistic cognition between Americans and Chinese result from the social norms of their respective societies. Chinese society is tighter than American society and exhibits greater social and institutional punishment for norm deviance, which should result in Chinese feeling more constraint across contexts. Consequently, it would be adaptive for Chinese to pay attention to both focal and peripheral events, cues, and objects and what they mean in relation to other environmental features.  The perceived constraint will be manipulated with a pictorial priming task to examine the effect on four measures of analytic and holistic cognition. Findings from these experiments are expected to contribute to the resolution of an important theoretical debate in cross-cultural psychology that concerns the basic motivational underpinnings of cultural behavior. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

por.por_cntn:
Americans and Chinese think about and perceive the world differently. Americans often focus their attention on specific objects in their field of vision and view them as independent from other objects in their environment. This cognitive style is known as analytic. By contrast, Chinese often focus their attention on all objects in their field of vision and view them as interdependent with their environment. This cognitive style is known as holistic. But why do Chinese and Americans differ in this regard? In collaboration with Dr. Shihui Han of Peking University in Beijing, China, an expert in cross-cultural psychology and social neuroscience, I devised this project to investigate potential explanations beyond those currently offered in the field of cross-cultural psychology.

I suggest that the differences in analytic and holistic cognition between Americans and Chinese result from the social norms of their respective societies, and the perception of constraint that these norms create among individuals in both countries. Chinese society is "tighter" than American society and exhibits greater social and institutional punishment for norm deviance, which should result in Chinese feeling more constrained across contexts. In other words, Chinese may feel unable to enact certain behaviors, lest they experience negative repercussions. In these environments, it would therefore be adaptive for Chinese to pay attention to both focal and peripheral events, cues, and objects and what they mean in relation to other environmental features, as this may be important for indicating how they should behave.

In contrast, Americans are exposed to "looser" environments that are chronically lower in constraint, and can afford to pay less attention to the peripheral cues of their environment. Consequntly, this may be the reason that they exhibit an analytic style of cognition.

If it is indeed the case that perceptions of constraint influence the cognitive styles that are differentially and predominantly expressed in each country, it is hypothesized that altering an individual's perception of felt constraint may cause them to shift from one cognitive style to another. Past research with American participants supports this. In particular, manipulating American participants to feel more constrained causes them to pay greater attention to the situational factors and how these factors influence behavior. This occurrence is demonstrative of holistic cognition and is typically found amongst Chinese participants.

To test this hypothesis, this project sought to make Chinese participants feel less constrained. It used a pictorial priming task and examined the effect of this manipulation on two measures of analytic and holistic cognition. At present, this project is still actively being pursued and its hypothesis still being investigated.

Ultimately, this research will lead to greater understanding about the causes of cultural differences in cognition and perception. Moreover, it will foster greater collaboration between scientists and researchers in the United States and China, bringing greater diversity in ideas, methods, and theory to the field of psychology.
